commits.message:
Merge pull request #512 from AzureAD/test-for-py3.11

Test matrix covers Python 3.11

Merge pull request #513 from AzureAD/new-region-endpoint

Switch to new region endpoints
Test only Python versions available on github's ubuntu 22.04
Fallback to expires_on when expires_in is absent

Merge pull request #519 from AzureAD/support_expires_on

Fallback to expires_on when expires_in is absent
Show lab api error, useful when trying api params
Clarify when (not) to read API section

Use broker for SSH Cert feature

It is OK to use PyMsalRuntime now, since ESTS has deployed the fix.
https://identitydivision.visualstudio.com/Engineering/_workitems/edit/2060332

Merge pull request #515 from AzureAD/enable-msalruntime-for-ssh-cert

Use broker for SSH Cert feature
Allow using client_id as scope. Needed by B2C.

Merge pull request #530 from AzureAD/allow-client_id-as-scope

Allow using client_id as scope. Needed by B2C.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -1728,9 +1702,62 @@ class PublicClientApplication(ClientApplication):  # browser app or mobile app
     def __init__(self, client_id, client_credential=None, **kwargs):
         """Same as :func:`ClientApplication.__init__`,
         except that ``client_credential`` parameter shall remain ``None``.
+
+        .. note::
+
+            You may set enable_broker_on_windows and/or enable_broker_on_mac to True.
+
+            What is a broker, and why use it?
+
+            A broker is a component installed on your device.
+            Broker implicitly gives your device an identity. By using a broker,
+            your device becomes a factor that can satisfy MFA (Multi-factor authentication).
+            This factor would become mandatory
+            if a tenant's admin enables a corresponding Conditional Access (CA) policy.
+            The broker's presence allows Microsoft identity platform
+            to have higher confidence that the tokens are being issued to your device,
+            and that is more secure.
+
+            An additional benefit of broker is,
+            it runs as a long-lived process with your device's OS,
+            and maintains its own cache,
+            so that your broker-enabled apps (even a CLI)
+            could automatically SSO from a previously established signed-in session.
+
+            ADFS and B2C do not support broker.
+            MSAL will automatically fallback to use browser.
+
+            You shall only enable broker when your app:
+
+            1. is running on supported platforms,
+               and already registered their corresponding redirect_uri
+
+               * ``ms-appx-web://Microsoft.AAD.BrokerPlugin/your_client_id``
+                 if your app is expected to run on Windows 10+
+               * ``msauth.com.msauth.unsignedapp://auth``
+                 if your app is expected to run on Mac
+
+            2. installed broker dependency,
+               e.g. ``pip install msal[broker]>=1.25,<2``.
+
+            3. tested with ``acquire_token_interactive()`` at least.
+
+        :param boolean enable_broker_on_windows:
+            This setting is only effective if your app is running on Windows 10+.
+            This parameter defaults to None, which means MSAL will not utilize a broker.
+
+        :param boolean enable_broker_on_mac:
+            This setting is only effective if your app is running on Mac.
+            This parameter defaults to None, which means MSAL will not utilize a broker.
         """
         if client_credential is not None:
             raise ValueError("Public Client should not possess credentials")
+        # Using kwargs notation for now. We will switch to keyword-only arguments.
+        enable_broker_on_windows = kwargs.pop("enable_broker_on_windows", False)
+        enable_broker_on_mac = kwargs.pop("enable_broker_on_mac", False)
+        self._enable_broker = bool(
+            enable_broker_on_windows and sys.platform == "win32"
+            or enable_broker_on_mac and sys.platform == "darwin")
comment.body: Won't `enable_broker_on_windows and sys.platform == "win32" or enable_broker_on_mac and sys.platform == "darwin"` already return a `bool`? The casting seems to be unnecessary.

pull_request.title: Integration with Broker-on-Mac
pull_request.body:
This PR has been tested by an internal bug bash.

It will remain as a draft until the dependency `PyMsalRuntime 0.14` is released on PyPI.

issue.title: PublicClientApplication w/ Username and Password Flow Reveals Error-Code 7000218
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I have been attempting to use [username_password_sample.py](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/username_password_sample.py) to construct an application allowing an authorized user to run a script against the MS Graph API.

config.json:
```
{
    "authority": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/organizations",
    "client_id": "<my-azure-application-id>",
    "username": "<my-email>@<my-organization>.com",
    "password": "<my-password>",
    "scope": ["User.Read"],
    "endpoint": "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me"
}
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to our [off-the-shelf samples](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/tree/dev/sample) and pick one that is closest to your usage scenario. You should not need to modify the sample.
2. Follow the description of the sample, typically at the beginning of it, to prepare a `config.json` containing your test configurations
3. Run such sample, typically by `python sample.py config.json`
4. See the error
5. In this bug report, tell us the sample you choose, paste the content of the config.json with your test setup (which you can choose to skip your credentials, and/or mail it to our developer's email).

**Expected behavior**
A token can be retrieved, if the user is authorized.

**What you see instead**
```
Token acquisition failed
{'error': 'invalid_client', 'error_description': "AADSTS7000218: The request body must contain the following parameter: 'client_assertion' or 'client_secret'.\r\nTrace ID: b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300\r\nCorrelation ID: 6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab\r\nTimestamp: 2023-10-26 18:45:25Z", 'error_codes': [7000218], 'timestamp': '2023-10-26 18:45:25Z', 'trace_id': 'b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300', 'correlation_id': '6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab', 'error_uri': 'https://login.microsoftonline.com/error?code=7000218', 'claims': '{"access_token":{"capolids":{"essential":true,"values":["95216c5c-d0c0-41c0-b3d1-737556c043db"]}}}'}
Press Ctrl-C to stop.
```

**The MSAL Python version you are using**
1.24.1
**Additional context**
Using a home-grown script, I am able to retrieve a token using the ConfidentialClientApplication flows ([for automated access to the APIs](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/confidential_client_certificate_sample.py)) but not when using the PublicClientApplication, same error-conditions.

comment.body:
> If you go with a different route, by registering [different redirect_uri](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity-platform/msal-client-application-configuration#redirect-uri) for your same app, it shall be able to behave as a public client or a confidential client, based on which redirect uri was in use. I have seen same app using interactive_sample.py and Web App sample, when being deployed on different environments.

Just thought it worth following-up - it's thanks to this comment that I was able to enable dual-authentication (public / confidential) in the same application - my original configuration tried to used the same custom-address for both the web and desktop platforms, thus the conflict. That said - I found that the interactive flow is anyway needed for new users to 'consent' to the application's use, so it too will be involved in the final product. All in all, issue resolved 🥇 Thank you Ray.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -1224,6 +1225,12 @@ def acquire_token_silent(
             returned from the UserInfo Endpoint and/or in the ID Token and/or Access Token.
             It is a string of a JSON object which contains lists of claims being requested from these locations.
 
+        :param object auth_scheme:
comment.body: Based on offline discussion, we agreed on a short `PCA.is_pop_supported()`. It accepts no `scope` parameter thus implies that it is about client's POP readiness.

pull_request.title: AT POP for Public Client based on broker
pull_request.body:
This is the implementation of the [internal work item](https://identitydivision.visualstudio.com/Engineering/_workitems/edit/1791492), and [this internal design doc](https://identitydivision.visualstudio.com/DevEx/_git/AuthLibrariesApiReview?path=/PoPTokensProtocol/PoP_API_In_MSAL.md&_a=preview).
Currently, this PR provides a low level API to obtain a Proof-of-Possesson (PoP) access token.

We may add more end-to-end test case in the future. And we may provide a high-level API.

The beta preview of this feature is available by `pip install --ignore-installed git+https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python.git@pop`

issue.title: PublicClientApplication w/ Username and Password Flow Reveals Error-Code 7000218
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I have been attempting to use [username_password_sample.py](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/username_password_sample.py) to construct an application allowing an authorized user to run a script against the MS Graph API.

config.json:
```
{
    "authority": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/organizations",
    "client_id": "<my-azure-application-id>",
    "username": "<my-email>@<my-organization>.com",
    "password": "<my-password>",
    "scope": ["User.Read"],
    "endpoint": "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me"
}
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to our [off-the-shelf samples](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/tree/dev/sample) and pick one that is closest to your usage scenario. You should not need to modify the sample.
2. Follow the description of the sample, typically at the beginning of it, to prepare a `config.json` containing your test configurations
3. Run such sample, typically by `python sample.py config.json`
4. See the error
5. In this bug report, tell us the sample you choose, paste the content of the config.json with your test setup (which you can choose to skip your credentials, and/or mail it to our developer's email).

**Expected behavior**
A token can be retrieved, if the user is authorized.

**What you see instead**
```
Token acquisition failed
{'error': 'invalid_client', 'error_description': "AADSTS7000218: The request body must contain the following parameter: 'client_assertion' or 'client_secret'.\r\nTrace ID: b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300\r\nCorrelation ID: 6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab\r\nTimestamp: 2023-10-26 18:45:25Z", 'error_codes': [7000218], 'timestamp': '2023-10-26 18:45:25Z', 'trace_id': 'b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300', 'correlation_id': '6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab', 'error_uri': 'https://login.microsoftonline.com/error?code=7000218', 'claims': '{"access_token":{"capolids":{"essential":true,"values":["95216c5c-d0c0-41c0-b3d1-737556c043db"]}}}'}
Press Ctrl-C to stop.
```

**The MSAL Python version you are using**
1.24.1
**Additional context**
Using a home-grown script, I am able to retrieve a token using the ConfidentialClientApplication flows ([for automated access to the APIs](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/confidential_client_certificate_sample.py)) but not when using the PublicClientApplication, same error-conditions.

comment.body:
But wait, this github issue was talking about username password flow, wasn't it? That flow has its limitations, and not recommended.

If you go with a different route, by registering [different redirect_uri](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity-platform/msal-client-application-configuration#redirect-uri) for your same app, it shall be able to behave as a public client or a confidential client, based on which redirect uri was in use. I have seen same app using `interactive_sample.py` and Web App sample, when being deployed on different environments.

But overall, you are right that this kind of conversation is not exactly in the scope of this library. I would suggest you start a question in perhaps StackOverflow to crowdsource some how-to.

issue.title: PublicClientApplication w/ Username and Password Flow Reveals Error-Code 7000218
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I have been attempting to use [username_password_sample.py](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/username_password_sample.py) to construct an application allowing an authorized user to run a script against the MS Graph API.

config.json:
```
{
    "authority": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/organizations",
    "client_id": "<my-azure-application-id>",
    "username": "<my-email>@<my-organization>.com",
    "password": "<my-password>",
    "scope": ["User.Read"],
    "endpoint": "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me"
}
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to our [off-the-shelf samples](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/tree/dev/sample) and pick one that is closest to your usage scenario. You should not need to modify the sample.
2. Follow the description of the sample, typically at the beginning of it, to prepare a `config.json` containing your test configurations
3. Run such sample, typically by `python sample.py config.json`
4. See the error
5. In this bug report, tell us the sample you choose, paste the content of the config.json with your test setup (which you can choose to skip your credentials, and/or mail it to our developer's email).

**Expected behavior**
A token can be retrieved, if the user is authorized.

**What you see instead**
```
Token acquisition failed
{'error': 'invalid_client', 'error_description': "AADSTS7000218: The request body must contain the following parameter: 'client_assertion' or 'client_secret'.\r\nTrace ID: b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300\r\nCorrelation ID: 6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab\r\nTimestamp: 2023-10-26 18:45:25Z", 'error_codes': [7000218], 'timestamp': '2023-10-26 18:45:25Z', 'trace_id': 'b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300', 'correlation_id': '6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab', 'error_uri': 'https://login.microsoftonline.com/error?code=7000218', 'claims': '{"access_token":{"capolids":{"essential":true,"values":["95216c5c-d0c0-41c0-b3d1-737556c043db"]}}}'}
Press Ctrl-C to stop.
```

**The MSAL Python version you are using**
1.24.1
**Additional context**
Using a home-grown script, I am able to retrieve a token using the ConfidentialClientApplication flows ([for automated access to the APIs](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/confidential_client_certificate_sample.py)) but not when using the PublicClientApplication, same error-conditions.

comment.body:
After considering the spec and reevaluating the app-configuration, I did manage to get user-based authentication working. But as you mentioned, an application configured for use by public authentication flows cannot also be configured as a confidential-client application, and vise-versa. Two separate application profiles would be required - one for user-facing invocations and another for unattended operations.

Thanks again for pointing me in the right direction.

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I have been attempting to use [username_password_sample.py](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/username_password_sample.py) to construct an application allowing an authorized user to run a script against the MS Graph API.

config.json:
```
{
    "authority": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/organizations",
    "client_id": "<my-azure-application-id>",
    "username": "<my-email>@<my-organization>.com",
    "password": "<my-password>",
    "scope": ["User.Read"],
    "endpoint": "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me"
}
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to our [off-the-shelf samples](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/tree/dev/sample) and pick one that is closest to your usage scenario. You should not need to modify the sample.
2. Follow the description of the sample, typically at the beginning of it, to prepare a `config.json` containing your test configurations
3. Run such sample, typically by `python sample.py config.json`
4. See the error
5. In this bug report, tell us the sample you choose, paste the content of the config.json with your test setup (which you can choose to skip your credentials, and/or mail it to our developer's email).

**Expected behavior**
A token can be retrieved, if the user is authorized.

**What you see instead**
```
Token acquisition failed
{'error': 'invalid_client', 'error_description': "AADSTS7000218: The request body must contain the following parameter: 'client_assertion' or 'client_secret'.\r\nTrace ID: b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300\r\nCorrelation ID: 6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab\r\nTimestamp: 2023-10-26 18:45:25Z", 'error_codes': [7000218], 'timestamp': '2023-10-26 18:45:25Z', 'trace_id': 'b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300', 'correlation_id': '6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab', 'error_uri': 'https://login.microsoftonline.com/error?code=7000218', 'claims': '{"access_token":{"capolids":{"essential":true,"values":["95216c5c-d0c0-41c0-b3d1-737556c043db"]}}}'}
Press Ctrl-C to stop.
```

**The MSAL Python version you are using**

**Additional context**
Using a home-grown script, I am able to retrieve a token using the ConfidentialClientApplication flows ([for automated access to the APIs](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/confidential_client_certificate_sample.py)) but not when using the PublicClientApplication, same error-conditions.

comment.body:
It is actually an expected behavior, [defined in the specs](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-3.2.1):

    Confidential clients or other clients issued client credentials MUST
    authenticate with the authorization server

issue.title: PublicClientApplication w/ Username and Password Flow Reveals Error-Code 7000218
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I have been attempting to use [username_password_sample.py](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/username_password_sample.py) to construct an application allowing an authorized user to run a script against the MS Graph API.

config.json:
```
{
    "authority": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/organizations",
    "client_id": "<my-azure-application-id>",
    "username": "<my-email>@<my-organization>.com",
    "password": "<my-password>",
    "scope": ["User.Read"],
    "endpoint": "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me"
}
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to our [off-the-shelf samples](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/tree/dev/sample) and pick one that is closest to your usage scenario. You should not need to modify the sample.
2. Follow the description of the sample, typically at the beginning of it, to prepare a `config.json` containing your test configurations
3. Run such sample, typically by `python sample.py config.json`
4. See the error
5. In this bug report, tell us the sample you choose, paste the content of the config.json with your test setup (which you can choose to skip your credentials, and/or mail it to our developer's email).

**Expected behavior**
A token can be retrieved, if the user is authorized.

**What you see instead**
```
Token acquisition failed
{'error': 'invalid_client', 'error_description': "AADSTS7000218: The request body must contain the following parameter: 'client_assertion' or 'client_secret'.\r\nTrace ID: b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300\r\nCorrelation ID: 6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab\r\nTimestamp: 2023-10-26 18:45:25Z", 'error_codes': [7000218], 'timestamp': '2023-10-26 18:45:25Z', 'trace_id': 'b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300', 'correlation_id': '6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab', 'error_uri': 'https://login.microsoftonline.com/error?code=7000218', 'claims': '{"access_token":{"capolids":{"essential":true,"values":["95216c5c-d0c0-41c0-b3d1-737556c043db"]}}}'}
Press Ctrl-C to stop.
```

**The MSAL Python version you are using**
1.24.1
**Additional context**
Using a home-grown script, I am able to retrieve a token using the ConfidentialClientApplication flows ([for automated access to the APIs](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/confidential_client_certificate_sample.py)) but not when using the PublicClientApplication, same error-conditions.

comment.body:
> I believe when your app was registered with client credentials in the Azure Portal, it is expected to always be used with its
> credential (i.e., programming with MSAL's ConfidentialClientApplication). 

Thanks @rayluo - this was something I was unaware of. It's unfortunate if that's the case, but at that point the issue lies not with this library so much as with my understanding of which ways the library could be used under different scenarios.

issue.title: PublicClientApplication w/ Username and Password Flow Reveals Error-Code 7000218
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I have been attempting to use [username_password_sample.py](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/username_password_sample.py) to construct an application allowing an authorized user to run a script against the MS Graph API.

config.json:

```
{
    "authority": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/organizations",
    "client_id": "<my-azure-application-id>",
    "username": "<my-email>@<my-organization>.com",
    "password": "<my-password>",
    "scope": ["User.Read"],
    "endpoint": "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me"
}
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to our [off-the-shelf samples](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/tree/dev/sample) and pick one that is closest to your usage scenario. You should not need to modify the sample.
2. Follow the description of the sample, typically at the beginning of it, to prepare a `config.json` containing your test configurations
3. Run such sample, typically by `python sample.py config.json`
4. See the error
5. In this bug report, tell us the sample you choose, paste the content of the config.json with your test setup (which you can choose to skip your credentials, and/or mail it to our developer's email).

**Expected behavior**
A token can be retrieved, if the user is authorized.

**What you see instead**
```
Token acquisition failed
{'error': 'invalid_client', 'error_description': "AADSTS7000218: The request body must contain the following parameter: 'client_assertion' or 'client_secret'.\r\nTrace ID: b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300\r\nCorrelation ID: 6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab\r\nTimestamp: 2023-10-26 18:45:25Z", 'error_codes': [7000218], 'timestamp': '2023-10-26 18:45:25Z', 'trace_id': 'b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300', 'correlation_id': '6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab', 'error_uri': 'https://login.microsoftonline.com/error?code=7000218', 'claims': '{"access_token":{"capolids":{"essential":true,"values":["95216c5c-d0c0-41c0-b3d1-737556c043db"]}}}'}
Press Ctrl-C to stop.
```

**The MSAL Python version you are using**
1.24.1
**Additional context**
Using a home-grown script, I am able to retrieve a token using the ConfidentialClientApplication flows ([for automated access to the APIs](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/confidential_client_certificate_sample.py)) but not when using the PublicClientApplication, same error-conditions.

commits.message: add Benchmark (pytest) benchmark result for b3b2195ff66e14f15f7b50fcd7e2e01d87b202f2

issue.title: [Feature Request] Improve default token caching
issue.body:
As a repair item from incidents where client_credentils apps were not using cached tokens: 

- [ ] Produce an indication that the token comes from the cache (e.g. boolean AuthenticationResult.IsFromCache or AuthenticationResult.TokenSource - IdP, TokenCache, Broker)
- [ ] Allow apps to do static caching (i.e. shared per process), e.g. `cca.WithCacheOptions(SharedCache)`
- [ ] Update client_creds samples to showcase the 2 new APIs.

pull_request.title: Expose token_source for observability
pull_request.body:
This will address #602 's first requirement. The successful token acquisition result will have a new key `token_source` whose value will be `idp`, `cache` or `broker`.

Existing unit test cases have been updated to test this new behavior.

issue.title: PublicClientApplication w/ Username and Password Flow Reveals Error-Code 7000218
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I have been attempting to use [username_password_sample.py](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/username_password_sample.py) to construct an application allowing an authorized user to run a script against the MS Graph API.

config.json:
```
{
    "authority": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/organizations",
    "client_id": "<my-azure-application-id>",
    "username": "<my-email>@<my-organization>.com",
    "password": "<my-password>",
    "scope": ["User.Read"],
    "endpoint": "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me"
}
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to our [off-the-shelf samples](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/tree/dev/sample) and pick one that is closest to your usage scenario. You should not need to modify the sample.
2. Follow the description of the sample, typically at the beginning of it, to prepare a `config.json` containing your test configurations
3. Run such sample, typically by `python sample.py config.json`
4. See the error
5. In this bug report, tell us the sample you choose, paste the content of the config.json with your test setup (which you can choose to skip your credentials, and/or mail it to our developer's email).

**Expected behavior**
A token can be retrieved, if the user is authorized.

**What you see instead**
```
Token acquisition failed
{'error': 'invalid_client', 'error_description': "AADSTS7000218: The request body must contain the following parameter: 'client_assertion' or 'client_secret'.\r\nTrace ID: b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300\r\nCorrelation ID: 6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab\r\nTimestamp: 2023-10-26 18:45:25Z", 'error_codes': [7000218], 'timestamp': '2023-10-26 18:45:25Z', 'trace_id': 'b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300', 'correlation_id': '6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab', 'error_uri': 'https://login.microsoftonline.com/error?code=7000218', 'claims': '{"access_token":{"capolids":{"essential":true,"values":["95216c5c-d0c0-41c0-b3d1-737556c043db"]}}}'}
Press Ctrl-C to stop.
```

**The MSAL Python version you are using**
1.24.1
**Additional context**
Using a home-grown script, I am able to retrieve a token using the ConfidentialClientApplication flows ([for automated access to the APIs](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/confidential_client_certificate_sample.py)) but not when using the PublicClientApplication, same error-conditions.

comment.body:
> Token acquisition failed
{'error': 'invalid_client', 'error_description': "AADSTS7000218: The request body must contain the following parameter: 'client_assertion' or 'client_secret'.\r\nTrace ID: b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300\r\n..., 'error_uri': 'https://login.microsoftonline.com/error?code=7000218', 'claims': '{"access_token":{"capolids":{"essential":true,"values":["95216c5c-d0c0-41c0-b3d1-737556c043db"]}}}'}

> Also reproduced using the [interactive_sample.py](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/interactive_sample.py), same error-conditions

I believe when your app was registered with client credentials in the Azure Portal, it is expected to always be used with its credential (i.e., programming with MSAL's `ConfidentialClientApplication`). You can try to change the `username_password_sample.py` sample and run it one more time. Keep in mind though, the [username password flow has its own quirks](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/wiki/Username-Password-Authentication) so that you may run into other errors.

Existing unit test cases have been updated to test this new behavior.

issue.title: PublicClientApplication w/ Username and Password Flow Reveals Error-Code 7000218
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I have been attempting to use [username_password_sample.py](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/username_password_sample.py) to construct an application allowing an authorized user to run a script against the MS Graph API.

config.json:
```
{
    "authority": "https://login.microsoftonline.com/organizations",
    "client_id": "<my-azure-application-id>",
    "username": "<my-email>@<my-organization>.com",
    "password": "<my-password>",
    "scope": ["User.Read"],
    "endpoint": "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me"
}
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to our [off-the-shelf samples](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/tree/dev/sample) and pick one that is closest to your usage scenario. You should not need to modify the sample.
2. Follow the description of the sample, typically at the beginning of it, to prepare a `config.json` containing your test configurations
3. Run such sample, typically by `python sample.py config.json`
4. See the error
5. In this bug report, tell us the sample you choose, paste the content of the config.json with your test setup (which you can choose to skip your credentials, and/or mail it to our developer's email).

**Expected behavior**
A token can be retrieved, if the user is authorized.

**What you see instead**
```
Token acquisition failed
{'error': 'invalid_client', 'error_description': "AADSTS7000218: The request body must contain the following parameter: 'client_assertion' or 'client_secret'.\r\nTrace ID: b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300\r\nCorrelation ID: 6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab\r\nTimestamp: 2023-10-26 18:45:25Z", 'error_codes': [7000218], 'timestamp': '2023-10-26 18:45:25Z', 'trace_id': 'b041fb2d-9d65-4e12-833a-d95065208300', 'correlation_id': '6965ec8e-fe4b-416f-b918-7960caf26cab', 'error_uri': 'https://login.microsoftonline.com/error?code=7000218', 'claims': '{"access_token":{"capolids":{"essential":true,"values":["95216c5c-d0c0-41c0-b3d1-737556c043db"]}}}'}
Press Ctrl-C to stop.
```

**The MSAL Python version you are using**
1.24.1
**Additional context**
Using a home-grown script, I am able to retrieve a token using the ConfidentialClientApplication flows ([for automated access to the APIs](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/blob/dev/sample/confidential_client_certificate_sample.py)) but not when using the PublicClientApplication, same error-conditions.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -63,6 +63,7 @@ def acquire_and_use_token():
     result = global_app.acquire_token_for_client(scopes=config["scope"])
 
     if "access_token" in result:
+        print("Token was obtain from:", result["token_source"])  # Since MSAL 1.25
comment.body:
FYI, @bgavrilMS , this is what I meant by ["the string literals become the real API"](https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-python/pull/610#discussion_r1373509560).

BTW, all the built-in samples in this repo have been updated with this line. So, this will also satisfy the last requirement of #602 .
